Brønsted acid generation of alumina-supported molybdenum oxide calcined at high temperatures: Characterization by acid-catalyzed reactions and spectroscopic methods Tomoyuki Kitano a Shota Okazaki a Tetsuya Shishido a b ⁎ Kentaro Teramura a b c Tsunehiro Tanaka a b ⁎ a Department of Molecular Engineering, Kyoto University Katsura, Nishikyo-ku, Kyoto 615-8510, Japan b Elements Strategy Initiative for Catalysts & Batteries Kyoto University, Kyoto 615-8520, Japan c Precursory Research for Embryonic Science and Technology (PRESTO), Japan Science and Technology Agency (JST), 4-1-8 Honcho, Kawaguchi, Saitama 332-0012, Japan ⁎ Corresponding authors at: Department of Molecular Engineering, Kyoto University Katsura, Nishikyo-ku, Kyoto 615-8510, Japan. Tel.: +81 75 383 2559; fax: +81 75 383 2561. Graphical abstract Highlights ► Brønsted acid sites were generated on MoO3/Al2O3 calcined at high temperature. ► Brønsted acid property depended on calcination temperature and loading amount. ► 11wt% MoO3/Al2O3 calcined at 1073K exhibited the highest Brønsted acidity. ► MoO3 is mainly loaded as monolayer domain on 11wt% MoO3/Al2O3. ► Brønsted acid sites were mainly generated on boundaries of monolayer domains. The acidic properties of alumina-supported molybdenum oxide (MoO3/Al2O3) calcined at high temperatures, with MoO3 loadings of 5–30wt%, were investigated using acid-catalyzed reactions (benzylation of anisole and isomerization of α-pinene), and Fourier-transformed infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR). The structure of MoO3 on Al2O3 was characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS), and X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) analysis. The correlation between acidic property and structure is discussed. Brønsted acid sites, where acid-catalyzed reactions take place, are generated on MoO3/Al2O3 by calcination at high temperatures. 11wt% MoO3/Al2O3 calcined at 1073K exhibited the highest activity, and the largest numbers of Brønsted acid sites were generated. XPS and Mo K-edge XAFS revealed that molybdenum oxide monolayer domains with distorted MoO6 units and small MoO3 clusters were formed and molybdenum oxide monolayer domains were stabilized on alumina below 11wt% of MoO3 loading. Brønsted acid sites are probably generated at boundaries between molybdenum oxide monolayer domains and/or small MoO3 clusters. When the MoO3 loading was sufficient to form two-dimensional molybdenum oxide overlayers (>11wt%), some of the Brønsted acid sites on MoO3/Al2O3 was covered with Al2Mo3O12 having no Brønsted acid site, resulting in a lowering of the catalytic activity. Keywords Solid acid catalyst Molybdenum oxide High temperature calcination Brønsted acid site Alumina 1 Introduction Molybdenum oxide catalysts are used in the wide range of petrochemical industry. Molybdenum oxide is usually used with supported on an inorganic oxide support (TiO2, SiO2, Al2O3, and ZrO2) to improve catalytic activity and selectivity, life, and mechanical strength. Supported molybdenum oxides often show a good catalytic performance for selective oxidation of hydrocarbons [1], oxidative dehydrogenation of alkanes [2], and metathesis of olefins [3]. In the case of MoO3/ZrO2, it was reported that the catalyst exhibited high activity for acid–base reactions such as cracking of hexane [4], benzoylation of toluene [5], and hydrolysis of ethyl acetate [6,7]. MoO3/ZrO2 exhibits unique acid property; Arata [8] reported that MoO3/ZrO2 was one of the solid superacid catalysts and showed the highest acid strength to be H0 ≦−13. Okuhara [6,7] reported that the MoO3/ZrO2 catalyst exhibits hydrophobicity and the acid property was enhanced by addition of water. On the other hand, MoO3/Al2O3 is active for epoxidation of allyl alcohol [9], oxidative dehydrogenation of propane [10,11], and hydrodesulfurization of thiophene [12]. The activity and the active sites for selective oxidation [13] and hydrodesulfurization [12] were investigated. However, there are few reports discussing the relation between structure and acidic property of acid sites on MoO3/Al2O3. Recently, we reported that Brønsted acid sites were generated on Nb2O5/Al2O3 and Ta2O5/Al2O3 calcined at 1123K and 1223K despite calcination at high temperatures, which usually caused disappearance of acidic property. Niobic acid (Nb2O5·nH2O, hydrated niobium oxide) is effective for reactions that relate to aqueous media including esterification, olefin hydration, alcohol dehydration and exhibits Brønsted acid property [14–19]. However, niobic acid loses their acid property when calcined at 773K due to phase transformation [20]. On the other hand, Nb2O5/Al2O3 calcined at high temperature such as 1123K showed activity in benzylation of anisole, cumene cracking, and isomerization of α-pinene, which proceeded on Brønsted acid sites. In a series of Nb2O5/Al2O3 catalyst, 16wt% Nb2O5/Al2O3 calcined at 1123K exhibited the highest activity and Brønsted acidity [21–23]. Moreover, Nb2O5/Al2O3 calcined at 1123K maintained the activity for isomerization of α-pinene even after pretreatment at 1173K. The result means that the Brønsted acid sites generated on Nb2O5/Al2O3 calcined at 1123K are thermally quite stable. Ta2O5/Al2O3 calcined at 1223K also shows activity for benzylation of anisole and isomerization of α-pinene and exhibits Brønsted acid property [24,25]. Hydrated tantalum oxide shows mainly Lewis acid properties in the absence of water, but water treatment causes generation of Brønsted acid sites [26,27]. Hydrated tantalum oxide loses the acid property by calcination at 1073K, but 33wt% Ta2O5/Al2O3 calcined at 1223K exhibits the highest Brønsted acid property. These facts strongly suggest that alumina support plays a role of generation of thermally stable Brønsted acid sites and Nb2O5/Al2O3 and Ta2O5/Al2O3 calcined at high temperatures work as thermally stable solid acid catalysts. The acidic property of Nb2O5/Al2O3 and Ta2O5/Al2O3 depends on both calcination temperature and loading amount due to structural change of Nb2O5 and Ta2O5. Based on characterization of Nb2O5/Al2O3 and Ta2O5/Al2O3, we proposed that niobium oxide and tantalum oxide were loaded as monolayer on alumina and concerned with generation of Brønsted acid sites. Many researchers investigated the structure of molybdenum oxide supported on alumina calcined at moderate temperatures (773–873K) [9–11,13,28,29]. Isolated tetrahedral species are formed at very low loading amount of MoO3 (under 5wt%). On the other hand, octahedral polymolybdates are produced at higher loading amount than 5wt%. When the MoO3 loading is sufficient to form two-dimensional molybdenum oxide overlayers, MoO3 crystal or Al2Mo3O12 are formed on alumina. However, few papers reported the structure of molybdenum oxide supported on alumina calcined at higher temperatures than 873K. Furthermore, the relation between the structure of molybdenum and the activity for selective oxidation [9], oxidative dehydrogenation [11], and hydrodesulfurization [12] on MoO3/Al2O3 has been often studied. The relation between the structure of molybdenum oxide and the acidic property is still unclear. In the present study, we investigated structural change in a series of alumina-supported molybdenum oxide catalysts with various loadings of MoO3 (5–30wt%) and calcined at various temperatures (773–1123K) to clarify the correlation between their acidic properties and local structures around molybdenum species. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation A series of MoO3/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by impregnation of γ-Al2O3 (JRC-ALO-8) with an aqueous solution of ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O) at 353K, dried overnight at 353K, and calcined at various temperatures for 3h in a dry air. Aluminum molybdate, Al2Mo3O12, was synthesized from Al(NO3)3·9H2O and (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O. Al(NO3)3·9H2O was dissolved in an aqueous solution and then oxalic acid (Wako, Osaka, Japan) and 28% ammonia solution were added to pH of 1.0 and 3.0, respectively. An aqueous solution of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O was added to an aluminum solution in a ratio of Al/Mo=0.67, and refluxed at 413K for 1h. The white paste obtained by removing water was dried at 423K for 15h, and Al2Mo3O12 was formed by calcination of the solid at 1023K for 4h. MoO3 was obtained by calcination of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O at 773K for 3h. 2.2 Reactions Benzylation of anisole (Friedel–Crafts alkylation of anisole with benzylalcohol) and isomerization of α-pinene were employed as test reactions to examine the acid properties of MoO3/Al2O3. Benzylation of anisole was examined in a liquid phase. The catalysts (0.2g) was pretreated in a N2 flow at 473K for 1h and added to a mixture of benzyl alcohol (6.25mmol) and anisole (92.5mmol) in a 100ml flask. The reaction was carried out at 383K for 0.5h and the products were determined by GLC (GC-14B with a flame ionization detector, Shimadzu, Kyoto, Japan) and GC–MS (Shimadzu GC–MS QP-5050), using a CBP10 column. Isomerization of α-pinene was carried out under a dry N2 atmosphere using a stirred batch reactor. Prior to each run, 0.05g of sample was pretreated at 673K under 13.3kPa of O2 for 1h and followed by evacuation at the same temperature for 1h. α-Pinene (12.5mmol) was added in the reactor and stirred at 323K for 3h. The products were determined by GLC (Shimadzu GC-2014 with a flame ionization detector), using a CBP20 column. 2.3 Characterizations The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) specific surface area was estimated from N2 isotherm at 77K. The N2 adsorption isotherm measurements were carried out using a BELSORP 28SA (BEL Japan, Osaka, Japan) at 77K. Prior to the measurement, each sample was evacuated at 673K for 2h. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using a MultiFlex DR Powder X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku, Tokyo Japan), using Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.5405Å). Laser Raman spectra were obtained using an NRS-2000 Raman Spectrometer (JASCO, Tokyo, Japan), using 514.5nm line of an argon laser. The spectral resolution was 4cm−1. FT-IR spectra were recorded using a SPETRUM ONE FT-IR spectrometer (Perkin-Elmer, Walthham, MA) with a resolution of 4cm−1. Each sample (13mg) was pressed into a self-supporting wafer (diameter 13mm). The catalysts were pretreated under 6.7kPa of O2 for 1h at 673K and then evacuated for 1h at 673K. For determination of the number of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites on MoO3/Al2O3, the wafer was exposed to 0.667kPa of pyridine vapor at 298K for 10min followed by evacuation at 423K for 10min. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) of the catalysts were acquired using an ULVAC PHI 5500MT system equipped with a hemispherical energy analyzer. Samples were mounted on indium foil and then transferred to an XPS analyzer chamber. The residual gas pressure in the chamber during data acquisition was less than 1.33×10−6 Pa. The spectra were measured at room temperature using Mg Kα radiation. The electron take-off angle was set at 45°. Binding energy was referenced to O 1s level. X-ray absorption experiments were carried out on the BL01B1 at SPring-8 (Hyogo, Japan). The ring energy was 8GeV, and the stored current was 99.5mA. The Mo K-edge (20.0keV) X-ray absorption spectra were recorded in transmission mode in air or in N2 at room temperature. A Si (311) and a Si (111) two crystal monochromator were used to obtain monochromatic X-ray beam. The data reduction was performed by the REX2000 Ver.2.5.9 (Rigaku) and FEFF8.40 programs [30]. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Catalysis Fig. 1 a shows the results of benzylation of anisole over 11wt% MoO3/Al2O3 calcined at various temperatures. In this reaction, p- and o-benzyl anisoles were mainly formed and dibenzyl ether was minor product. Formation of multiply alkylated products was not observed. This reaction takes place on Brønsted acid sites and benzyl anisole is produced [31–37]. Dibenzyl ether is produced on Lewis acid sites due to dehydration between two molecules of benzyl alcohol. The amount of dibenzyl ether was less than 0.08mmol in every reaction. The yield of benzyl anisole strongly depended on the calcination temperature and increased with increasing calcination temperature up to 1073K. When the catalyst was calcined at 1123K, the yield decreased. The ratio of p-benzyl anisole to o-benzyl anisole was ca. 8/7 regardless of calcination temperature. The results of isomerization of α-pinene over 11wt% MoO3/Al2O3 calcined at various temperature is summarized in Table 1 . Isomerization of α-pinene is used for a test reaction to investigate acid–base property and acid strength of the catalyst [38–40]. The main products over MoO3/Al2O3 were camphene and limonene, and the selectivities to camphene and limonene were ca. 57% and 33%, respectively. The minor products were β-pinene, fenchene, α-terpinene, γ-terpinene, and terpinolene. Products are divined in three groups (Scheme 1 ). The first group is β-pinene, which is produced on basic sites. The second group is bicyclic compound such as camphene and fenchene, and the last group is monocyclic compound such as limonene, terpinolene, α-terpinene, and γ-terpinene. Ohnishi [41] and Yamamoto [38,40] reported that monocyclic and bicyclic compound such as camphene and limonene were produced on Brønsted acid sites and the fraction was changed by the maximum strength of acid sites of the catalyst. The selectivity strongly depends on acidic and basic property of the catalyst. Because camphene and limonene were mainly produced on MoO3/Al2O3, MoO3/Al2O3 catalysts mainly exhibit Brønsted acid property. Fig. 1b shows yields of camphene and limonene produced over 11wt% MoO3/Al2O3 calcined at various temperatures. The yields increased with rise in calcination temperature up to 1073K as well as benzylation of anisole. The selectivity of camphene and limonene was almost constant with the change in calcination temperature. These results suggest that calcination temperature affects only the number of acid sites. The results of benzylation of anisole over MoO3/Al2O3 calcined at 1073K with various MoO3 loading are shown in Fig. 2 a. The yield of benzyl anisole was also strongly affected by loading amount of MoO3. Alumina was almost inactive. And the yield of benzyl anisole rapidly increased with increase of MoO3 loading above 8wt%. The 11wt% MoO3/Al2O3 exhibited the highest activity and then activity decreased sharply over 11wt%. The ratio of p-benzyl anisole to o-benzyl anisole was ca. 8/7 regardless of MoO3 loading amount. This suggests that the acid strength was independent on the MoO3 loading, whereas the number of acid sites varied. Effects of MoO3 loading amount on the activity of α-pinene isomerization were investigated. The change in yields and selectivities of camphene and limonene are shown in Fig. 2b and Table 2 . On alumina, the main products were camphene, limonene, and β-pinene, but activity is quite low. With increase of loading amount up to 8wt%, the selectivities to camphene and limonene slightly increased and that to β-pinene decreased. The selectivity was almost constant from 8wt% to 30wt%. On the other hand, the conversion increased with rise of MoO3 loading up to 11wt% and then decreased. The yields of camphene and limonene changed sharply. The result shows the conversion strongly depends on loading amount. It is suggested that the acidity increased and the acid strength changed by increase of loading amount up to 8wt%. And the retention of selectivity at 8–30wt% indicates that only the number of acid sites increased or decreased without change in the acid strength with loading amount at 8–30wt%. Because calcination temperature and loading amount of MoO3 strongly affected the activity for benzylation of anisole and isomerization of α-pinene, acidic property of MoO3/Al2O3 catalyst was investigated by pyridine adsorbed FT-IR spectra. We evaluated the amount of acid sites from the specific amount of the adsorbed pyridinium ions for Brønsted acid sites and pyridine coordinated to Lewis acid sites over each MoO3/Al2O3 catalyst. Fig. 3 shows IR spectra of adsorbed pyridine on 11wt% MoO3/Al2O3 calcined at 1073K and Al2O3, respectively. The spectrum of alumina exhibited four bands at 1447, 1490, 1578, and 1609cm−1. These four bands correspond to pyridine species adsorbed on Lewis acid site [42,43]. On the other hand, MoO3/Al2O3 gave new bands at 1545 and 1639cm−1 corresponding to pyridine species adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites and the bands at 1623, 1495, and 1455cm−1 were shifted to 1613, 1490, and 1451cm−1, respectively. Appearance of bands at 1545 and 1639cm−1 on MoO3/Al2O3 means Brønsted acid sites are generated by the addition of molybdenum oxide on alumina and are maintained even after calcination at high temperatures [42,43]. Shifts of bands at 1623, 1495, and 1455cm−1 indicated that Lewis acid property was changed by loading of molybdenum oxide. To determine whether the activities for benzylation of anisole and isomerization of α-pinene were controlled by the amount of Brønsted acid sites, the specific amounts of pyridinium ion on Brønsted acid sites and of pyridine coordinated to Lewis acid sites on each MoO3/Al2O3 catalyst were evaluated from the area of band of adsorbed pyridine. The number of Brønsted acid site was calculated using an integrated molar adsorption coefficient value of ɛ =1.67cmμmol−1 for the band area at 1545cm−1 of protonated pyridinium ion [44,45]. Fig. 4 shows the number of Brønsted acid sites of 11wt% MoO3/Al2O3 calcined at various temperatures. The Brønsted acidity increased with increase of calcination temperature up to 1073K and the calcination at 1123K resulted in reduction of Brønsted acidity. This result showed that high temperature calcination is important for generation of Brønsted acid sites. Fig. 5 shows the Brønsted acidity of MoO3/Al2O3 calcined at 1073K with various MoO3 loadings. Al2O3 did not exhibit Brønsted acid property. Brønsted acidity increased with rise of MoO3 loading, and 11wt% MoO3/Al2O3 exhibited the highest Brønsted acidity. Then Brønsted acidity decreased over 11wt% loading. Fig. 6 shows the correlation between the activities and number of Brønsted acid sites. The activities for benzylation of anisole and isomerization of α-pinene strongly depended on Brønsted acidity and a good correlation was shown between the activities and Brønsted acidity. These results exhibit that benzylation of anisole and α-pinene isomerization proceeded on Brønsted acid sites generated on MoO3/Al2O3 calcined at high temperatures. The amount of Lewis acidity was calculated using an integrated molar adsorption coefficient value of ɛ =2.22cmμmol−1 for the band area at 1450cm−1 of coordinated pyridine [44,45]. Lewis acidity decreased with increase of calcinations temperature and MoO3 loading amount, indicating that no Lewis acid site concerned with these reactions (Figs. S1 and S2). 3.2 Characterizations Figs. 7 and 8 show XRD patterns and Raman spectra of 11wt% MoO3/Al2O3 calcined at various temperatures. Molybdenum oxide was not crystalized on MoO3/Al2O3 calcined below 1123K. Al2Mo3O12 was formed on MoO3/Al2O3 calcined at 1123K. The results showed that MoO3 was loaded as amorphous phase. Because benzylation of anisole and isomerization of α-pinene did not proceed on Al2Mo3O12 and no Brønsted acid sites existed on Al2Mo3O12, formation of Al2Mo3O12 caused decrease of Brønsted acid sites on MoO3/Al2O3 calcined at 1123K. Figs. 9 and 10 show XRD patterns and Raman spectra of MoO3/Al2O3 calcined at 1073K with various MoO3 loading. XRD patterns and Raman spectra of MoO3/Al2O3 showed no diffraction pattern and Raman peak due to Al2Mo3O12 crystalline until the MoO3 reached 11wt%. Above 13wt%, Al2Mo3O12 appeared and Al2Mo3O12 crystal grew with increase of loading amount. Considering the results of change in acid property, because of the formation of Al2Mo3O12, Brønsted acid sites decreased over MoO3/Al2O3 with higher MoO3 loading than 11wt%. From these results, it can be thought that amorphous molybdenum oxide concern with generation of Brønsted acid sites. The surface Mo/Al ratios on MoO3/Al2O3 catalysts were estimated from the areas in the Mo 3d and Al 2p XP spectra. Binding energy of Mo 3d5/2 and Mo 3d3/2 peaks of the catalysts is 232.7 and 235.9eV respectively and did not change regardless of calcination temperature and loading amount of MoO3. This result indicates that the valence of molybdenum cation of MoO3/Al2O3 catalyst were Mo6+ regardless of calcination temperature and MoO3 loading amount. No significant change was shown in the surface Mo/Al ratio of 11wt% MoO3/Al2O3 calcined at various temperature, indicating Mo atoms were located on the surface regardless of calcination temperature without sublimation of MoO3. Fig. 11 shows the surface Mo/Al ratio of MoO3/Al2O3 calcined at 1073K with various MoO3 loading. The surface Mo/Al ratio shows a linear increase with loading of MoO3 up to 10wt% then the line becomes gradual. The cross-section area of MoO6 octahedral unit is 0.22nm−2 and surface area of the catalyst [11]. It is estimated that the surface of MoO3/Al2O3 is completely covered with monolayer of molybdenum oxide when the molybdenum content is 10wt% as MoO3. The results suggest that monolayer of molybdenum oxide was formed on 10wt% MoO3/Al2O3 and three-dimensional MoO3 clusters seem to coexist above 10wt%. Considering the results of XRD and Raman spectra, two-dimensional molybdenum oxide domains are mainly formed and a little of three-dimensional MoO3 clusters are contained on 11wt% MoO3/Al2O3. Three-dimensional MoO3 clusters are transformed to Al2Mo3O12 and Al2Mo3O12 increases with increase of loading amount above 11wt%. Taking into account the change in the number of Brønsted acid site, we concluded that stabilized monolayer of molybdenum oxide and small MoO3 clusters account for the generation of Brønsted acid sites. The local structure of MoO3/Al2O3 catalysts was characterized by Mo K-edge XAFS spectra. Fig. 12 shows Mo K-edge X-ray adsorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectra of MoO3/Al2O3 calcined at 1073K with various loading and reference samples. The pre-edge peak at Mo K-edge XANES, which is assigned to transition of 1s to d–p orbitals, is sensitive to the symmetry. X-ray absorptions have been often used to provide information on the local symmetry [46–48]. The molybdenum oxide unit on a sample is distorted from an ideal octahedral symmetry, the pre-edge peak of Mo K-edge XANES become intense. Therefore, a pre-edge peak of Na2MoO4 (MoO4 tetrahedral) is much more intense than that of molybdenum oxide (distorted octahedral) is, and that of SrCaMoO3 (MoO3 octahedral) is much less intense than that of molybdenum oxide. The pre-edge peaks of MoO3/Al2O3 are larger than that of MoO3 and smaller than that of Na2MoO4, indicating that the coordination symmetry around Mo of MoO3/Al2O3 is distorted octahedral symmetry. The area was slightly decreased up to 11wt%. Above 13wt%, this value gradually increased and approached to that of Al2Mo3O12. The shape of spectra of 5–11wt% MoO3/Al2O3 in the range of 20.02–20.06eV resemble each other. Above 13wt%, the two peaks at around 20.25 and 20.45eV grew with increase of loading amount. These results indicate that the formation of Al2Mo3O12 proceeds when the MoO3 loading was larger than 11wt%. The Mo K-edge k 3-weighted extended X-ray adsorption fine structure (EXAFS) oscillations of MoO3/Al2O3 catalysts with various loadings and reference samples are shown in Fig. 13 . No significant changes in the EXAFS spectra of each MoO3/Al2O3 catalyst appeared until the MoO3 loading was 11wt%. The oscillation amplitude decreased monotonically with k, suggesting that a smaller Mo(O)Mo contribution than that in bulk MoO3. On the other hand, the configuration changed in EXAFS oscillations of 13–30wt% MoO3/Al2O3 catalysts. Appreciable oscillation appeared in the k region higher than 8Å−1, and the oscillation is similar to that of Al2Mo3O12, indicating that there is a Mo(O)Al contribution on the catalyst. The oscillation in the k region higher than 6Å−1 grew remarkably in the EXAFS oscillation of 20 and 30wt% MoO3/Al2O3 catalysts, which indicates growth of Al2Mo3O12 crystal. In the case of 13wt% MoO3/Al2O3 catalyst, it appears that a small amount of Al2Mo3O12 was present together with monolayer of molybdenum oxide. Therefore, these results indicate that the local structure of molybdenum cation of MoO3/Al2O3 catalysts with loading of MoO3 up to 11wt% is maintained and Al2Mo3O12 crystal is mixed to the loaded molybdenum oxide with increase of MoO3 loading over 11wt%. Fig. 14 shows Fourier transformed EXAFS oscillations of MoO3/Al2O3 catalysts with various loadings and reference samples. Until 11wt%, only one peak at 1.3Å was shown and new peak at 3.3Å appeared and grew on MoO3/Al2O3 with higher MoO3 loading than 11wt%. The two peaks at 1.3 and 3.3Å are corresponded to MoO and Mo(O)Al linkages. The peak at 3.3Å is assigned by analyzing the backscattering amplitudes and the phase shifts. Because the atomic numbers of Al (13) and Mo (42) is different, the back scattering amplitude of Al and the phase shift of the Mo(O)Al are different from those of the Mo(O)Mo pair. In the structure of Al2Mo3O12 crystal, there is no Mo(O)Mo linkages but Mo(O)Al linkages and increase of the peak at 3.3Å means that Al2Mo3O12 crystal is mixed to the loaded molybdenum oxide with increase of MoO3 loading over 11wt%. These results agree with the results of XPS measurement. Physical property of MoO3/Al2O3 calcined at 1073K is summarized in Table 3 . The catalyst areas include that of the alumina carrier. S 0 is the surface area g(Al2O3)−1 of a carrier, and was calculated from the BET specific surface area and MoO3 content. S occupied is the estimated area occupied by MoO6 unit (0.22nm2). It is assumed that all of MoO3 is loaded as MoO6 octahedra and the area of that is 0.22nm2. The surface area of MoO3/Al2O3 decreased with loading amount of MoO3 due to a shrink of alumina support and at sudden decrease of surface area was shown at 10wt%. The areas of alumina support (S 0) decrease and the area occupied by MoO6 units (S occupied) increase with loading amount of MoO3 and S occupied become larger than S 0 at 10wt%. The surface density of Mo atom on 8 and 10wt% MoO3/Al2O3 calcined at 1073K is estimated to be 2.8 and 5.6atomsnm−2, respectively. Because some researchers suggested that the surface density of Mo atoms in monolayer coverage with MoO3 was 4.5atomnm−2 and the value was larger than the surface density of Mo atom on 8wt% and a little smaller than 10wt%[10], these results mean that MoO3 was loaded as two-dimensional molybdenum oxide until 8wt% and formation of three-dimensional MoO3 just started on 10wt% MoO3/Al2O3. In discussing where the Brønsted acid sites generated, there are some important points. (1) The activity and Brønsted acidity increased with loading amount, but the tendency of increase became larger up to 11wt%. (2) Brønsted acidity is much smaller than the number of supported Mo atoms. (3) The Brønsted acidity strongly depended on loading amount, but the acid strength was not changed with loading amount. On the basis of the results above, we concluded that two-dimensional molybdenum oxide and a small cluster of MoO3 were the keys to the generation of Brønsted acid sites. We assumed three models on the structure of Brønsted acid sites generated on MoO3/Al2O3 (Fig. 15 ). One is hydroxyl groups formed on molybdenum oxide monolayer domain and three-dimensional MoO3 (MoOH or Mo(OH)Mo) work as Brønsted acid sites. And the second model means hydroxyl groups formed on the edges of molybdenum oxide monolayer domain and three-dimensional MoO3 (molybdenum oxide domain; Mo(OH)Al) work as Brønsted acid sites. In the last model, they are located at the boundaries of molybdenum oxide monolayer domain and three-dimensional MoO3. The relation between the number of Brønsted acid sites and the Mo content strongly suggests that model 3, isolated or bridged hydroxyl groups located at the boundaries of molybdenum oxide islands, is the most reliable among the proposed models. Until 8wt%, only molybdenum monolayer was formed on alumina and small clusters of MoO3 are mixed over 8wt%. Because Brønsted acidity sharply increased from 8wt%, Brønsted acid sites are generated on the boundary of both of molybdenum monolayer domain and small clusters of MoO3. Generation of Brønsted acid sites by calcination at high temperatures is assumed to be due to (1) the formation of MoO3 monolayer domains and small clusters of MoO3 on the surface of alumina, and (2) the formation of boundaries of molybdenum oxide monolayer domains and MoO3 small clusters. The shrink of alumina by calcination at high temperatures contributes to the reduction of surface area of alumina. As a result, the distance between domains of molybdenum oxide monolayer and small clusters of MoO3 becomes shorter, and then, boundaries of molybdenum monolayer domain and small clusters of MoO3 form to generate Brønsted acid sites. 4 Conclusions MoO3/Al2O3 calcined at high temperature exhibited reaction activity (benzylation of anisole and isomerization of α-pinene) and Brønsted acidity. The acid property of MoO3/Al2O3 strongly depended on calcination temperature and MoO3 loading and high calcination temperature (1073K) was effective for generation of Brønsted acid sites. 11wt% MoO3/Al2O3 calcined at 1073K exhibited the highest reactivity and Brønsted acidity. On the catalyst, molybdenum oxide monolayer domains and small clusters of MoO3 were formed on alumina and covered the surface on this catalyst. Brønsted acid sites are generated on the boundary of molybdenum oxide monolayer domains and small clusters of MoO3. Over 11wt%, molybdenum oxide monolayer domains and small clusters of MoO3 translated to inert Al2Mo3O12 and Brønsted acid sites disappeared. coredata.dc:description: The acidic properties of alumina-supported molybdenum oxide (MoO3/Al2O3) calcined at high temperatures, with MoO3 loadings of 5–30wt%, were investigated using acid-catalyzed reactions (benzylation of anisole and isomerization of α-pinene), and Fourier-transformed infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR). The structure of MoO3 on Al2O3 was characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS), and X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) analysis. The correlation between acidic property and structure is discussed. Brønsted acid sites, where acid-catalyzed reactions take place, are generated on MoO3/Al2O3 by calcination at high temperatures. 11wt% MoO3/Al2O3 calcined at 1073K exhibited the highest activity, and the largest numbers of Brønsted acid sites were generated. XPS and Mo K-edge XAFS revealed that molybdenum oxide monolayer domains with distorted MoO6 units and small MoO3 clusters were formed and molybdenum oxide monolayer domains were stabilized on alumina below 11wt% of MoO3 loading. Brønsted acid sites are probably generated at boundaries between molybdenum oxide monolayer domains and/or small MoO3 clusters. When the MoO3 loading was sufficient to form two-dimensional molybdenum oxide overlayers (>11wt%), some of the Brønsted acid sites on MoO3/Al2O3 was covered with Al2Mo3O12 having no Brønsted acid site, resulting in a lowering of the catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: Brønsted acid generation of alumina-supported molybdenum oxide calcined at high temperatures: Characterization by acid-catalyzed reactions and spectroscopic methods
